issues.description: The problem statement refers to a method named `linkParent(Person person, Person parent)` (lines 101) but the template and solution define and expect a method named `addParent(Person person, Person parent)`. This name mismatch can confuse students looking for `linkParent` in the template code and in the tests to implement. Additionally, the explanatory sentence about saving the relation mixes variable names (it says "add `parent` to the `person`'s list of parents" but uses the example `linkParent(person: Person, parent: Person)` and later refers to "child"), which may further confuse which parameter represents the child vs. the parent.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement to use the same method name as the template and solution (use `addParent(Person person, Person parent)` everywhere). Also clarify the example wording to avoid mixing variable names: e.g. "addParent(person: Person, parent: Person): add the parent to the person's set of parents (i.e., person is the child in this call). Save and return the updated person." This keeps the specification consistent with the provided code and tests.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to the method as `linkParent(Person person, Person parent)` (lines 100–106) while the template and solution code define and expect the method named `addParent(Person person, Person parent)`. This inconsistent identifier for the same conceptual operation (adding a parent to a person) can confuse students about which method they should implement and which name the tests and REST endpoints expect.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the name across artifacts. Update the problem statement to refer to `addParent(Person person, Person parent)` (instead of `linkParent(...)`) so it matches the template and solution, REST endpoints, and test expectations. If the intent was `linkParent`, rename the method in template and solution to `linkParent` everywhere (including tests and REST mapping) — but the simpler fix is to correct the problem statement to `addParent`.
